How to Build a Blog Scraper

By Jane Smith | January 15, 2024

Building a blog scraper is a fascinating challenge that combines web crawling, HTML parsing, and content extraction techniques. In this guide, we'll walk through building a production-quality system that works on any blog without site-specific selectors.

Getting Started

First, you need to understand the structure of the blog you want to scrape. The key insight is that blogs, despite their visual variety, all have similar structural patterns: a title, some metadata, and a body of content.

import scrapy

class BlogSpider(scrapy.Spider):
    name = 'blog'
    start_urls = ['https://example.com/blog']

    def parse(self, response):
        for article in response.css('article'):
            yield {'title': article.css('h1::text').get()}

Handling Different Templates

Different blogs use different page templates. The key is to use deterministic algorithms rather than site-specific CSS selectors. This approach ensures your scraper works across thousands of different blog designs.

  • Use readability-lxml for main content extraction
  • Fall back to trafilatura if readability fails
  • Use DOM heuristics as a last resort

Extracting Metadata

Most modern blogs include rich metadata in JSON-LD, Open Graph, or Twitter Card format. By parsing these structured data sources first, we can reliably extract the title, author, publication date, and tags without scraping the visual HTML.

The best scrapers are the ones that work on any site without modification.

Performance Considerations

When scraping at scale, you need to be polite to the servers you're crawling. Use Scrapy's AutoThrottle middleware to automatically adjust your crawl speed based on server latency. Respect robots.txt and add appropriate delays between requests.

With these techniques, you can build a scraper that reliably extracts content from virtually any blog on the internet, regardless of its technical stack or visual design.
